PHRASE.Comment: This is the only entry for this key.
The names of the liturgical months in the nominative case, that is, for use in the format 'Month 2008'.
The names of the liturgical week in the nominative case, that is, for use in the format 'Year Month Date Week'.
The names of the liturgical months in the genitive case, that is, for use in the format 'Wednesday, 28 March 2008'.
The names of the civil months in the genitive case, that is, for use in the format 'Wednesday, 28 March 2008'.
The names of the civil week in the nominative case, that is, for use in the format 'Year Month Date Week'.

PHRASE.Comment: This is the å­—é«” to be used for é¡¯ç¤º all the relevant information on screen for the Main interface. A blank entry of "" will é¸æ“‡ the default å­—é«”.
The size of the å­—é«” for the Main interface, since some èªžè¨€s need a larger å­—é«” size to be legible. A blank entry will give the default value of 12.

This is the å­—é«” to be used for é¡¯ç¤º information in the Liturgical aspect. At times, the å­—é«” of the Liturgics will be different from that of the main Screen (for example, Russian interface; Church Slavonic Liturgics).
The size of the å­—é«” for the Liturgics aspect (see FontFaceL) for explanation, since some èªžè¨€ need a larger å­—é«” size to be legible. A blank entry will give the default value of 12.
This is the mark to separate the different commemorations that are é¡¯ç¤º.
This is the mark to separate the readings.
This is for everytime that a colon is required.

This is the 2 letter ISO code for the given èªžè¨€. This will also determine component orientation, for example left-to-right, right-to-left (Hebrew, Arabic, Farsi), top-right-to-bottom-left (Traditional Chinese, Korean, Japanese), and top-left-to-bottom-right (Traditional Mongolian).
This is the 2 letter ISO code for the given country. This may be required later on for some things.

This is the Unicode location for the starting point of the numbers. Changing it to a different starting point will allow any non-Western decimal system to be used. For 'Arabic' numerals (0,1,2,3,4,5...) the starting point is 0!
This allows ideographic numerals to be é¡¯ç¤º instead of the normal decimal based values, that is, 145 will be é¡¯ç¤º as for example, CXLV. 1 = yes!
This gives the format for the time. The 24-hour clock will be used.

PHRASE.Note: This is how a colon is to appear in the given texts.

PHRASE.Comments: %getN is a generalised grammar engine that will return the appropriate grammatical form. The format is Noun (in this case to be specified so ^CC) and the desired case (as defined in the commemoration files)
Failure to find any name for a given commemoration!

PHRASE.Note: This allows the time value to be displayed with at least the given number of digits. Must be equal to or greater than 1
This allows the time value to be displayed with at least the given number of digits. Must be equal to or greater than 1

This determine the order in which the Month Year selection boxes in the Main display for the calendar are displayed. MM implies that the month will come first, while YY implies that the year will do so.

There is no need to include the current language and its path up, as it will be searched by default. Similarly, only the lowest desired searachable path should be considered, as the programme will by default search up the tree from the given point.
This displays the anno mundi year in brackets in the calendar, only for the Julian date
This determines whether or not the Anno Mundi value will be displayed. 1 = Yes, 0 = No.
This determines whether the AM value comes before (B) the rest of the date or after (A) it
This is a relative path to the default icon desired for the case where there is no icons available.
